Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3783492 Resolving a Paradox: Retail Trades Positively Predict Returns but are Not Profitable Abstract Retail order imbalance positively correlates with returns in the days following trades. However, in aggregate, retail investor trades lose money over these same periods. Why? 1) While order imbalance tests value or equally weight stocks, retail purchases are concentrated in stocks earning large negative abnormal returns. 2) Order imbalance tests ignore losses on the day of trade. Our results reconcile the literatures on the performance of retail investors, the predictive content of retail order imbalance, and attention-induced trading and returns. We also find evidence that trades by retail investors with less knowledge, experience, and wealth are more likely to underperform. Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3783492

At short horizons, the order imbalance of retail investors positively predicts future returns. Both of these seemingly contradictory statements about retail investors are well-established. Several studies of retail investors (using a variety of datasets, methods, and horizons) show that in aggregate retail investors earn poor returns at both short horizons, e.g. less than a month, and longer horizons, e.g. more than a month (Barber and Odean, 2000, 2001; Odean, 1999; Grinblatt and Keloharju, 2000; Chen, Kim, Nofsinger, and Rui, 2007; Barber, Lee, Liu, and Odean, 2009; Jones, Shi, Zhang, and Zhang, 2020). In contrast, several studies of retail investors (using a variety of datasets, methods, and horizons show that retail order imbalance positively predicts future returns at short horizons (Barber, Odean, and Zhu, 2008; Hvidkjaer, 2008; Kaniel, Saar, and Titman, 2008; Kaniel, Liu, Saar, and Titman, 2012; Kelley and Tetlock, 2013; Barrot, Kaniel, and Sraer, 2016; Boehmer, Jones, Zhang, and Zhang, 2020).1 Papers reach different conclusions about the profitability of retail trades. Odean (1999) finds that â€œeven when trading costs are ignored, these investors actually lower their returns through tradingâ€ (p. 1296). Grinblatt and Keloharju (2000) write that â€œthe least sophisticated investors (households)â€¦ generate the worst performanceâ€ (p. 66). And Barber, Lee, Liu, and Odean (2008) conclude that â€œindividual investor trading results in systematic and economically large lossesâ€ (p. 609). In contrast many order imbalance papers interpret the positive correlation between retail order imbalance and short-term future returns as evidence that retail investors profit from trading. One reason retail order imbalance may positively forecast short-term returns is that retail investors have insider information (or are able to predict future returns from public information). Kaniel, Liu, Saar, and Titman (2012) interpret the ability of retail order imbalance to predict returns around earnings and dividend announcements as â€œevidence consistent with informed or skillful trading by individual investorsâ€ (p. 677). Another reason why order imbalance may positively forecast short-term returns is that retail investors are contrarians who buy (sell) stocks that institutions want to sell (buy) and reap short-term rewards for providing liquidity. Kaniel, Saar, and Titman (2008) propose that retail order imbalance forecasts returns because individuals â€œprovide liquidity to meet institutional demand for immediacyâ€ (p. 273) leading to retail investor profits at horizons of 20 days or longer. An alternative explanation for the short-term predictability of retail order imbalance is that retail order imbalance is positively serially correlated. Barber, Odean, and Zhu (2008) document this correlation and argue that order imbalance positively predicts short- term returns because it predicts price pressure. Finally, Boehmer, Jones, Zhang, and Zhang (2020) write that â€œpersistence in order flow, and order flow driven by return reversals (our proxy for liquidity provision), accounts for about half of the predictive power of the marketable retail order imbalance for future returns, and we attribute the other half to potential informed tradingâ€ (p. 3). The two literatures summarized above present a paradox: Over short horizons, in aggregate retail investors lose by trading, but retail order imbalance positively predicts future returns. In this paper, we reconcile these two empirical observations. The paradox can be traced to two key issues. First, order imbalance studies tend to equal or value weight stocks while investor performance depends upon the extent to which investors buy and sell each stock. Stocks with positive order imbalance but relatively little retail trading subsequently perform well while retail purchases with the most retail trading perform miserably. As we discuss in detail below, the tendency for retail investors to herd into stocks that subsequently perform lines up well with an emerging literature that documents attention-induced buying by retail investors predicts poor returns. Second, order imbalance studies often ignore trading losses on the day of trade. As a result of these two factors, there is a large difference between hypothetical trading strategies based on retail order imbalance and the returns actually earned by retail investors. A value- weighted long-short portfolio based on retail order imbalance measured on day t and held through t+1 yields impressive annualized alphas of 5.74%. In contrast, a long-short portfolio that buys and shorts in proportion to aggregate retail trading over the same horizon generates an annualized alpha of -2.32%. These differences are even more striking among small stocks (bottom third of stocks based on market cap). Among these small stocks, equal-weighted order imbalance strategies generate a daily alpha of 16.2 bps (an annualized alpha greater than 40%), but a trade-weighted long-short portfolio that mimics the buys and sells of retail investors earns -11.2 bps (an annualized alpha of less than -28%). Our empirical analysis is based on US retail trades, which we identify in the Trades and Quote (TAQ) dataset from 2010-2019 using the price improvement algorithm described in Boehmer, Jones, Zhang, and Zhang (BJZZ, 2020). The alphas from these order imbalance strategies range from a few basis points for big stocks to more than 16 bps for small stocks. The predictive ability of retail order imbalance is greatest for small stocks, consistent with the results in BJZZ (2020). These trading strategies indicate retail order imbalance is positively correlated with short-term future returns. However, the positive return on these long-short portfolios does not answer a related but distinct question: Do retail investors in aggregate profit from trading in the short-term? They do not. Using the same retail order imbalance dataset derived from TAQ 2010-2019, we calculate the trade- weighted returns on stocks bought less the trade-weighted returns on stocks sold on day t assuming the stocks are traded at observed transaction prices on day t and held through the close of t+1. We also consider holding periods ranging from t+1 and t+10. In Figure 1, Panel B, we summarize the abnormal returns for big, medium, and small stocks. In sharp contrast to the profitable trading strategies based on retail order imbalance, these results indicate that the average retail investor loses by trading. The losses range from a few basis points in big stocks to more than 20 basis points for small stocks. The analysis confirms results in prior studies that document aggregate short-term losses by retail investors (Odean, 1999; Barber, Lee, Liu, and Odean, 2009; Jones, Shi, Zhang, and Zhang, 2020). As discussed above, there are two key reasons why retail investors lose money trading over the short horizons that we analyze even though their order imbalance positively predicts returns. The first reason is that retail buying is concentrated in stocks that perform poorly. Within the quintile of stocks with the greatest positive retail order imbalance, the stocks most aggressively purchased by retail investors substantially underperform. Thus though an equal or value-weighted portfolio of stocks with positive retail order imbalance performs well, a purchase-weighted portfolio of the same stocks does not. For example, the daily equal-weighted alpha on stocks in the top order imbalance quintile is +3.65 bps the next day (t=6.31). In sharp contrast, the purchase-weighted return on stocks in the same quintile of order imbalance is -4.47 bps (t=-3.02). Furthermore over 40% of all retail purchases occur in this top quintile of retail order imbalance. We then independently sort stocks into deciles of standardized abnormal retail trading volume and quintiles of retail order imbalance. The average stock in the top quintile of retail order imbalance and the top decile of abnormal retail volume earns an alpha of -5.78 bps (t=-2.62) the day after the trade; in contrast, the average stock in the top quintile of retail order imbalance but below the top decile of standardized abnormal retail volume earns an alpha of 3.74 bps (t=6.92). The observation that stocks with a combination of high levels of retail volume and disproportionate retail buying underperform connects to a number of studies that document attention-induced return effects from retail trading. When searching for stocks to buy, retail investors can choose from any stock in the market. However, when selling retail investors tend to sell that which they own. This asymmetry in the search problem of investors leads to coordinated attention-induced buying by retail investors which, in theory, can lead to predictably poor returns (Barber and Odean, 2008). Consistent with this narrative, the stocks with the biggest increase in users on the popular Robinhood app tend to earn poor returns (Barber, Huang, Odean and Schwarz, 2020). Similarly, a number of studies document price reversals following attention grabbing events: Jim Kramerâ€™s stock recommendations (Engelberg, Sasseville, and Williams, 2012; Keasler and McNeil, 2010; Bolster, Trahan and Venkateswaran, 2012), the WSJ Dartboard Column (Liang, 1999; Barber and Loeffler, 1993), Google stock searches (Da, Engelberg, and Gao, 2011; Da, Hua, Hung and Peng, 2020), and repeat news stories (Tetlock, 2011). We contribute to this literature by documenting that stocks with a combination of high retail order imbalance and abnormal retail volume earn reliably poor returns. Furthermore, a large proportion of all retail buying is concentrated in these stocks. The second reason why retail investors lose money trading at short horizons even though their order imbalance positively predicts returns over the same horizon is that retail investors lose money on the day that they trade. The losses on the day of trade are often ignored in the analysis of returns based on retail order imbalance and are alone sufficient to offset any subsequent trading gains.3 In aggregate, the same- day trading losses can be traced to the effective bid-ask spread that investors pay for transacting. This result reinforces previous findings that indicate a large portion of investor losses in can be traced to trading costs which include commissions, spreads, and (in some jurisdictions) transaction taxes (Barber and Odean, 2000; Barber, Lee, Liu, and Odean, 2009; Barrot, Kaniel, and Sraer, 2016). Thus, though transaction costs have declined substantially in the last several decades, spread costs alone are sufficient to offset aggregate short-term gains earned by retail trading. However, because retail buying is concentrated in stocks that perform poorly, even when we assume counterfactual transactions with zero spreads, in aggregate stocks bought by retail investors fail to reliably beat stocks sold. These are precisely the same group of stocks that go on to earn poor returns in the coming days. In additional analyses, we show small trades perform worse than large trades. In brokerage data with demographic information, trade size is correlated with wealth, income, and self-reported measures of investment experience and knowledge. The purchases among small trades are also more heavily concentrated in the group of stocks with high retail order imbalance and heavy retail volume that perform dismally, which is consistent with the notion that small, less sophisticated traders are more likely to be influenced by attention. Thus, the observation that small trades underperform large trades suggests that wealthier, more sophisticated, investors earn better returns than others, consistent with prior evidence (Barber and Odean, 2000; Grinblatt and Keloharju, 2000; Li, Geng and Subramanyam, 2017; Campbell, Ramadorai and Ranish, 2019; Jones et al., 2020). Our main contribution is to reconcile two well-established yet seemingly contradictory facts about equity markets: (1) retail order imbalance positively predicts short-term returns (2) in aggregate retail investors lose money over the short-term by trading. Two observations reconcile these facts. First, retail investor buying is highly concentrated in stocks that subsequently underperform; this underperformance is particularly acute for stocks with high retail order imbalance and abnormally high retail volume. The concentration of retail buying in underperforming stocks is consistent with the literature that documents investors earn predictably poor returns following attention-grabbing events (Engelberg, Sasseville, and Williams, 2012; Keasler and McNeil, 2010; Bolster, Trahan and Venkateswaran, 2012; Liang, 1999; Barber and Loeffler, 1993; Da, Engelberg, and Gao, 2011; Da, et al., 2020; Tetlock, 2011; Barber, Huang, Odean and Schwarz, 2020). Second, investors lose money on the day of trade, mostly to spread costs. Prior studies have hypothesized that retail order imbalance positively predicts short-term returns because retail investors are informed or profit from providing liquidity. While some retail investors are undoubtedly informed and some may profit from providing liquidity, in aggregate retail investors lose money through trading in the short-term just as they do in the long-term. 1. Table 2, Panel B, present statistics on mean market cap and mean volume across stock-day observations for each quintile. Larger firms and firms with greater volume tend to end up in the extreme quintiles. We also observe firms with high levels of abnormal retail volume (ARV and SARV) end up in the extreme quintiles. This is partly because the larger volume of retail trades in these large, high-volume stocks allows for a more precise estimates of order imbalance. In contrast, if we sort on order imbalance based on number of trades, the extreme quintiles are populated by relatively small stocks (see Table A1), which represent a small percentage of total market volume. We prefer the standardized measure because it accounts for both the level of order imbalance and the precision with which it is estimated. Our empirical results do not hinge on this choice and we present parallel results for the unstandardized measure of order imbalance in the online appendix. A particularly important observation from Table 2 is the distribution of retail order imbalance across the five order imbalance quintiles, which we summarize in Figure 3. Volume is unusually high in both extreme order imbalance quintiles. As a result, trading is concentrated in these quintiles. text: We can convincingly conclude that small trades perform worse than large trades. Thus, the aggregate returns from trading overestimate the returns of most retail trades. And, since trade size varies with wealth, the percentage losses of less wealthy retail investors are likely larger than those of wealthier investors. 5. Conclusion We reconcile two well established yet seemingly contradictory empirical findings: 1) in the short-term retail traders underperform, and 2) retail trade order imbalance positively predicts short-term returns. Two key observations explain the paradox. First, retail performance is quite poor on the day trades execute. Most order imbalance studies do not include same day returns when evaluating the predictive value of retail trades. Second, retail buying is highly concentrated in trades that perform poorly. Order imbalance studies evaluate hypothetical equal-weighted and value-weighted portfolios strategies, not the actual returns retail investors earn on trades. Thus the trades of retail investors can be interpreted in a way that positively forecasts returns even though these trades, in aggregate, negatively impact retail investor performance. We tie the underperformance of retail trades to attention-based trading. We find that the purchases of retail investors perform worst when retail order imbalance is high and retail trading volume is high. This is consistent with the theoretical prediction that retail investors will be heavily on the buy side of the market when stocks catch their attention and that this buying will lead to temporary price increases followed by reversals (Barber and Odean, 2008). It is also consistent with the observation the emerging literature that links attention-grabbing events to subsequent negative abnormal returns.12 We also find that small trades, which tend to be made by less wealthy, less experienced, and less sophisticated investors are more concentrated in attention-grabbing stocks and perform worse than large trades. Several explanations have been offered for both the negative effect of trading on retail investor performance and the positive signal from retail order imbalance. These explanations are not mutually exclusive. Retail investors may make wealth reducing trades because they do not realize that they are at an informational disadvantage and expect their trades to perform well; in other words, they are overconfident in their ability to trade (Odean, 1998, 1999; Barber and Odean, 2000, 2001; Statman, Thorley, and Vorkink, 2006; Glaser and Weber, 2007). For example, in our analysis of quintile portfolios formed on the basis of day t SOI quintiles we find no abnormal returns on days t+11 to t+21 (Table 3, Panel D). Similarly, we find no evidence of abnormal returns in purchase-weighted and sales-weighted portfolios on days t+11 to t+21 (Table 4, Panel D). However, prior evidence based on small trades from TAQ shows retail order imbalance measured at longer horizons negatively predicts returns (Hvidkjaer, 2008; Barber, Odean, and Zhu, 2008). To determine whether this result is robust during our sample period, we regress week t returns on lags of standardized weekly order imbalance (the weekly analogue of our daily SOI measure). To facilitate the interpretation of the regression coefficients, the SOI variables are standardized to have a zero mean and unit standard deviation. As control variables we include lags of weekly returns (to capture short-term reversals), longer horizon returns (to capture momentum effects), market cap, book-to-market ratios, and week fixed effects. Standard errors are clustered by week to account for the cross-sectional correlation of returns. We summarize the results in Table A6 for all stocks and three firm size partitions (small, medium, and large). Consistent with the evidence in BJZZ (2020) and Barber, Odean, and Zhu (2008), we observe retail order imbalance reliably predict returns one week ahead primarily for small stocks. A one standard deviation increase on SOI in week t-1 predicts a week t return that is 2.0 bps higher for the average stock and 6.6 bps higher for the average small stock. In sharp contrast, the mean retail order imbalance observed in weeks t-5 to t-52 negatively predicts returns in week t. A one standard deviation increase in the mean SOI observed over these 48 weeks predicts a week t return that is 4.5 bps lower for the average stock and 17.6 bps lower for the average small stock. The bulk of our analysis in prior sections shows that despite the fact that daily retail order imbalance positively predicts returns over short horizons retail investors lose money by trading over the same horizon. The analysis in this section also indicates the short-term predictability of order imbalance reverses at longer horizons.
